summary: Pokemon Card of the Day #1564: Arcanine (Next Destinies #12)
title: Pokemon Card of the Day #1564: Arcanine (Next Destinies #12)
body:
Here you have a Pokemon with a very nice damage output, a solid Ability, and a type that got Energy acceleration to make discarding a lot less painful. That was a lot going for its success! It also had incredible competition, which made it hard to stand out. It sure looked like a good format for an attack like Fire Spin, though, so maybe Arcanine could get by even in the wild times of the Black & White era…

130 HP was pretty impressive for a Stage 1. It was at the level where Zekrom and Reshiram even needed a damage boost to take it down in one hit. That Water Weakness could be an issue with things like Kyurem, Vanilluxe, Keldeo EX, and Empoleon being good choices. All four loved having that to pick on. Arcanine also needed some help with switching if you wanted to salvage it since its Retreat Cost was 3.

Blazing Mane was an Ability that Burned the opponent’s attacking Pokemon if Arcanine was damaged while being your Active Pokemon. It even worked when Arcanine was Knocked Out! While Burn wasn’t an amazing Special Condition by any means, it was still better than nothing and there was no downside to this. It was just a nice bonus that would go off whenever you were using Arcanine.

Fire Spin was surprisingly good. 100 damage for 2 Fire and a Colorless Energy compared pretty well even in such a hard-hitting era of the game. There was, sadly, a coin flip, and a tails meant you discarded 2 Energy attached to Arcanine. Fire was a type that could get away with this a bit more easily, especially in the HGSS-On format that had Typhlosion support. Later formats didn’t have it quite as good but Emboar was better than nothing.

Arcanine was a pretty solid attacker. It was also never used because it was almost completely outclassed by Reshiram. Reshiram always had to discard Energy but was a Basic Pokemon, just as bulky, and more powerful. This made it almost impossible to justify using Arcanine in a serious deck. If Reshiram wasn’t there, Arcanine may have had enough to be seen at least a little. It still had its good traits and 100 damage was nothing to take lightly.

blog.name: sylispokeworldheadcanons
blog.title: But what if we all did live in a Pokemon world
blog.description: Hi I'm Syli and I think about Pokemon too much. Headcanons about how the Pokemon world might work. May not be 100% canon compatible. I also lift elements from different continuities/adaptations based on what I like. Asks and so forth are welcome, but I might be slow about answering. If you need anything tagged just let me know.

summary: any headcanons for the marill line?
question: any headcanons for the marill line?
answer: As per its Pokédex entry, Marill’s tail contains bouyant oil that lets it float on the surface. When in needs to dive, it swallows a large amount of water, which goes into specialized sacs, which outweighs the tail’s boyancy and lets it sink. When Marill needs to surface, it spits out this water and floats back up.

reblog.comment: As per its Pokédex entry, Marill’s tail contains bouyant oil that lets it float on the surface. When in needs to dive, it swallows a large amount of water, which goes into specialized sacs, which outweighs the tail’s boyancy and lets it sink. When Marill needs to surface, it spits out this water and floats back up.

When Marill needs to surface, it spits out this water and floats back up.

summary: I'm gonna watch "Our Planet" soon but I'm wondering how they'd deal with global warming affecting the animals in the Pokémon...
body:
I’m gonna watch “Our Planet” soon but I’m wondering how they’d deal with global warming affecting the animals in the Pokémon world. 🤔

Pokémon should really tackle that in a movie sometime.

summary: So the *curse* isn’t really that bad?
question: So the *curse* isn’t really that bad?
answer:
(In response to this answer)

On the one hand, your stuff falling over or going missing, getting lost, clumsiness, and other bits of bad luck might seem annoying, but pretty tame for a curse laid by an ancient and powerful beast.

On the other hand, if your Pokémon keep missing in battle, unnerved by the will-o’-wisps dancing at the edge of their vision, then that bad luck might be a problem.

On the one hand, your stuff falling over or going missing, getting lost, clumsiness, and other bits of bad luck might seem annoying, but pretty tame for a curse laid by an ancient and powerful beast.

On the other hand, if your Pokémon keep missing in battle, unnerved by the will-o’-wisps dancing at the edge of their vision, then that bad luck might be a problem.
